data.title: Famous people who have died in Scottsdale
data.meta_description: A look at some of the celebrities who've died in Scottsdale.
data.text:
When Gen. Seth McKee, a four-star general who was the highest-ranking survivor of the D-Day invasion of France during World War II, died Dec. 26, 2016, in Scottsdale, he joined a long list of famous people who passed away while in the city. Here are some of them.

Bob Crane (1978)

Bob Crane, actor, died June 29, 1978, at the age of 49. Crane was murdered in Scottsdale, where he was appearing in a play. He is best known for the TV show "Hogan's Heroes."

Buster Crabbe (1983)

Buster Crabbe, actor, died April 23, 1983, of a heart attack at the age of 75. Crabbe was the Olympic champion swimmer who played Flash Gordon and Buck Rogers in movies in the 1930s.

MORE: Scottsdale, PV popular spots for celebrities to play | Celebrity homes

Carl Hubbell (1988)

Baseball Hall of Fame member Carl Owen Hubbell died Nov. 21, 1988, at a Scottsdale hospital following injuries suffered in an automobile accident in Mesa. He was 85. Hubbell, a left-handed screwball pitcher, was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1947. He amassed a 253-154 record during 16 years with the New York Giants. He pitched 3,591 innings, winning 21 or more games five consecutive years, and helped the Giants win the National League pennant in 1933, 1936 and 1937.

Tom Fogerty (1990)

Tom Fogerty, musician, died Sept. 6, 1990, of respiratory failure at the age of 48. He was a member of Creedence Clearwater Revival.

Don Ameche (1993)

Don Ameche, actor, died Dec. 6, 1993, of cancer at the age of 85. The suave actor was a leading man in the 1930s and '40s, and revived his career with roles in Trading Places and Cocoon in the 1980s.

Maureen O'Sullivan (1998)

Maureen O'Sullivan, actor, died June 23, 1998, of heart failure at the age of 87. She played the wife of Tarzan and numerous other roles in the 1930s. She was Mia Farrow's mother. She is shown here in a scene from the 1934 classic "The Thin Man" with Myrna Loy (left) and William Powell.

Leon Sullivan (2001)

Leon Sullivan died April 24, 2001, of leukemia at the age of 78. He was a civil-rights pioneer and minister best known for creating the Sullivan Principles, which helped abolish apartheid in South Africa.

Joe Foss (2003)

Joe Foss died Jan. 1, 2003, after suffering an aneurysm at the age of 87. A medal of honor winner for his record in World War II, Foss in 1955 became South Dakota's youngest governor. He was president of the National Rifle Association from 1988 to 1990.

Elisabeth Kubler-Ross (2004)

Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, author, died Aug. 24, 2004, at the age of 78. A psychiatrist, she was known for her writing about death and dying.

George Mikan (2005)

George Mikan, basketball player, died June 1, 2005, while being treated for diabetes and kidney failure at the age of 80. One of the pioneers of professional basketball. He was one of the sport's first successful big men at 6 foot 10. He played in the 1940s and '50s for the Minneapolis Lakers.

Billy Preston (2006)

Billy Preston, musician, died June 6, 2006, at the age of 59. He had been in a coma after a heart infection. Sometimes known as the "Fifth Beatle," he had a successful career on his own as a pianist and singer.

Frank Sackton (2010)

Former Army Lt. Gen. Frank Sackton, who played a pivotal role during the American occupation of Japan after World War II and was a professor emeritus at Arizona State University who helped establish its College of Public Affairs, died Feb. 14, 2010, in Scottsdale. He was 97.

Ron Santo (2010)

Ron Santo, baseball player, died Dec. 2, 2010, of cancer at the age of 70. He was a longtime third baseman and announcer for the Chicago Cubs.

Harmon Killebrew (2011)

Harmon Killebrew, baseball player, died May 17, 2011, of cancer at the age of 74. A member of the baseball Hall of Fame, he was known as a power hitter, mostly with the Minnesota Twins.

Bil Keane (2011)

Cartoonist Bil Keane, who is best known for creating the cartoon "Family Circus," lived in Paradise Valley for nearly 50 years. Keane died of congestive heart failure in 2011 at the age of 89.

Bill and Susan Heywood (2012)

Valley radio legend Bill Heywood and his wife Susan died Jan, 4, 2012, in a Homewood Suites room in Scottsdale. The pair had committed suicide. In his distinguished career, which stretched back to the 1960s, Bill Heywood was named by industry publication Billboard as the No. 1 radio personality for three years.

James DePriest (2013)

James DePriest, musician, died Feb. 8, 2013, at the age of 76. Winner of the National Medal of the Arts, DePriest was a conductor, leading orchestras in Houston, New York, Washington, D.C., Portland and elsewhere. He broke racial barriers in the world of classical music.

Dennis Farina (2013)

Dennis Farina, actor, died July 22, 2013, from a blood clot in his lung at the age of 69. He was known for roles in "Law & Order" on television and "Get Shorty" in the movies.

James Hellwig (2014)

James Hellwig died April 8, 2014, of cardiovascular disease at the age of 54. Hellwig was known as the Ultimate Warrior, one of pro wrestling's biggest stars in the late 1980s.

Dick Wagner (2014)

Alice Cooper guitarist Dick Wagner died July 30, 2014, of respiratory failure at Scottsdale Healthcare Shea Medical Center. The guitarist, who also played on seminal recordings by Lou Reed, Peter Gabriel and Kiss, had been living in Fountain Hills, having moved to Arizona in 2004. He was 71.

Meadowlark Lemon (2015)

The ex-Globetrotters star known as the "clown prince," Meadowlark Lemon died in Scottsdale at the age of 83 on Dec. 27, 2015. The cause of death is unknown.

Joe Garagiola (2016)

Valley icon and Major League Baseball's colorful announcer, Joe Garagiola, a Scottsdale resident, died on March 23, 2016, at the age of 90. Garagiola was known around the globe as a baseball announcer for more than 30 years and as a member of the broadcasters' wing of the Baseball Hall of Fame.

Muhammad Ali (2016)

Boxing legend Muhammad Ali died in Scottsdale on June 3, 2016, at 74 years old. Ali had suffered from Parkinsonâ€™s disease since the 1980s. He was known around the world for his personality and social activism. In 1997, Ali lent his name to the Muhammad Ali Parkinson Center at Barrow Neurological Institute in Scottsdale to help raise awareness of the disease.

He made a rare public appearance during the 2016 Celebrity Fight Night, an annual fundraising event for the institute and received a standing ovation.

Gen. Seth McKee (2016)

Gen. Seth McKee, a four-star general, died Dec. 26, 2016, in Scottsdale. He was 100 years old.

McKee, the highest ranking survivor of D-Day, led a group of fighter planes during the invasion of Normandy, France, in June 1944. After the war, McKee held almost every rank in the Air Force. His final post before retiring from the Air Force in 1973 was as commander of NORAD, the anti-nuclear missile defense center in Colorado.
